item.title: Frontend AI Perk: Open-Source Open‑Lovable vs. Lovable — One‑Click Clone Any Website into a React App
item.content:encoded:
For engineers and creators who want to use AI to ship products faster and validate ideas more cost‑effectively.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Lovable has gone viral recently: you can chat to generate websites/apps, with pricing based on credits. It’s a fresh model and surprisingly fast. At the same time, the Mendable team released an open-source alternative open‑lovable: clone any website into a modern React app, run it locally, modify it, and extend it. For many teams, this route is more controllable and cost‑efficient.

What is open‑lovable?

Section titled “What is open‑lovable?”

In one sentence: Give it a URL, and in seconds it pulls page structure and assets and generates runnable Next.js/React code that you can develop locally. Under the hood it has two “engines”:

  • Firecrawl: crawls web content and converts it into LLM‑friendly structured data like Markdown/JSON/screenshots.
  • E2B Sandboxes: secure, isolated cloud sandboxes serving as an “AI code runtime,” letting agents run commands, read/write files, install packages, and access the network.

The official README clearly lists dependencies and steps (supports Anthropic, OpenAI, Gemini, or Groq — any/some combination). You’ll need E2B_API_KEY + FIRECRAWL_API_KEY, plus at least one model provider API key. Then npm run dev to try it at localhost:3000. License is MIT.

Key point: open‑lovable leans toward “clone + local control,” while Lovable is more of a “hosted AI app builder.”

What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?

Section titled “What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?”

Lovable is a chat‑based full‑stack app builder. It supports Agent/Chat/Code/visual editing, Figma import, and integrations like GitHub/Supabase/Stripe/Clerk — very friendly for non‑technical users and small teams; credit‑based billing, Pro starts at $25/month.

  • Agent Mode: it can “think, research, and change code” on its own — read code, debug, search docs, modify code, and test.
  • Visual Edits: click elements on the page to change copy/styles, and no credits are deducted.

The company’s growth is brisk — recent funding and revenue news suggest the category is validated.

Side‑by‑Side: open‑lovable vs. Lovable

Section titled “Side‑by‑Side: open‑lovable vs. Lovable”
Dimensionopen‑lovable (Open Source)Lovable (Commercial SaaS)
Core capabilityClone any website → generate Next.js/React code, develop locallyNatural‑language full‑stack generation, supports Agent/Chat/Visual Edits
Runtime formLocal/self‑hosted, MIT license, deeply modifiableHosted cloud, WYSIWYG
DependenciesFirecrawl crawling + E2B sandboxes + your chosen LLM providerBuilt‑in AI capabilities and many integrations
PricingOpen source free (you pay Firecrawl/E2B/model usage)Credit‑based, Pro from $25/month
AudienceDevs with frontend skills wanting fast clone + fast customizationTeams wanting zero‑barrier app/prototype with minimal code
Typical scenariosMigrate competitor/marketing pages; rebuild legacy stack into modern React0→1 prototypes, MVPs, internal tools, turning designs into code

(Sources: both products’ websites and docs/READMEs)

Hands‑On: 5‑Minute Local Setup for open‑lovable

Section titled “Hands‑On: 5‑Minute Local Setup for open‑lovable”
  1. Clone and install
  1. Configure environment variables (.env.local)
  1. Run

These steps and dependencies are clearly documented in the official README.

Tip: Firecrawl supports full‑site crawling/screenshots/Markdown/JSON; E2B sandboxes default to a 5‑minute lifetime, configurable.

Three Real Developer Scenarios

Section titled “Three Real Developer Scenarios”

Example 1: Competitor landing page → same‑day marketing site release

Section titled “Example 1: Competitor landing page → same‑day marketing site release”

Scenario: Marketing wants to A/B test a new copy/layout. Approach:

  • Use open‑lovable to clone a competitor page or your old landing page skeleton into React.
  • Locally wire copy, CTAs, and tracking scripts (GA/analytics).
  • Apply your design system/components, connect the backend form/CRM. Benefit: Finish “migrate + customize + ship” in hours, instead of re‑slicing assets and rewriting styles from scratch.

Tech note: Firecrawl extracts clean page content, reducing manual copy‑paste; Next.js structure is tidy, making CI/CD straightforward.

Example 2: Modernize an “it works but it’s old” site

Section titled “Example 2: Modernize an “it works but it’s old” site”

Scenario: The company site/docs run, but the stack is aging. Approach:

  • Clone the current site to generate modern React code.
  • Use E2B sandbox‑driven scripts for batch refactors (class naming, image optimization, extracting i18n, etc.).
  • Add Tailwind/your design system to unify visuals. Benefit: Re‑skin first without breaking functionality, improve maintainability, then iteratively extract components and data layers.

Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one

Section titled “Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one”

Scenario: Lots of new business ideas; leadership wants to “see something.” Approach:

  • Clone a public page from a similar product as the skeleton.
  • Use models to quickly swap in industry‑specific copy and inline interaction demos.
  • Integrate third‑party auth/payments/email (and migrate to a real backend later). Benefit: You have “something real” the same day. Reviews focus on product value rather than “we haven’t built the page yet.” (When you move toward production, switch to Cursor/local repo for continued evolution.)

If you want zero‑code 0→1, Lovable’s Agent/Visual Edits and integrations are smoother. The open‑source route fits teams that need engineering‑grade control of code.

Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain

Section titled “Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain”
  • GitHub Actions: on PRs, run Lighthouse/Playwright to watch performance and usability.
  • Supabase/Stripe/Clerk for MVP auth/payments/data. open‑lovable outputs standard React code, so integrate as usual; Lovable provides built‑in guides/templates for these services.
  • Model “mix‑and‑match”: use Claude/GPT‑5 for complex logic, Groq/Kimi K2 for speed; switch via env vars as needed.

How to Choose

Section titled “How to Choose”
  • You want to control code, cut subscriptions, and reuse existing web pages → open‑lovable.
  • You want 0→1 prototypes/internal tools fast, and value hosting and collaboration → Lovable.
  • Or use a combo: first use open‑lovable to grab the “shell” and refine locally; or validate product/flows in Lovable first, then “export/refactor” to self‑hosted.

Industry chatter often positions Lovable as “scaffolding + visual design/flow,” while serious projects return to local engineering for polishing. open‑lovable neatly covers the “engineering‑grade control” half.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI‑assisted development is bifurcating: one side is hosted, WYSIWYG (Lovable); the other is open‑source, controllable, engineering‑friendly (open‑lovable).
There’s no absolute right answer — your team’s cost/pace/governance needs matter most.

Which side do you lean toward? Where do you think open‑lovable fits best in your business? Share your real‑world scenarios in the comments.

item.title: As Claude Code Gets Stronger, Engineers Should Spend More Time on Architecture, Requirements, and Problem‑Solving
item.content:encoded:
Over the next 6–24 months, the direction of AI‑driven “Vibe Coding” will become ever clearer, and within 5 years the way we program will change dramatically; routine implementation and boilerplate coding will be highly automated, and engineers will spend more time on architecture, translating requirements, and creative problem‑solving. At the same time, don’t underestimate the speed and limits of this evolution. This captures the emerging consensus since the rise of AI coding assistants like Claude Code and Cursor.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Over the past year, you may have felt it: writing code is no longer “finishing a function,” but organizing intelligence and process. Cursor inside the IDE can “see the repo, run commands, and act as an executor.” Claude Code in the terminal brings Slash commands, Sub‑agents, and automated security reviews. This isn’t hype — it’s a new production line.

1) Where exactly are AI coding assistants strong?

Section titled “1) Where exactly are AI coding assistants strong?”
  • Code understanding and batch rewriting: Cursor’s Agent mode supports cross‑file exploration, edits, and multi‑turn fixes; Ask mode does read‑only retrieval to understand first, then modify.
  • Orchestratable workflows: Claude Code’s Slash Commands turn common actions into commands; Sub‑agents let different tasks use dedicated helpers with isolated context.
  • Built‑in security review: the official /security-review and GitHub Action can automatically scan PRs and suggest fixes.

Bottom line: the goal isn’t to “type a few extra lines for you,” but to turn requirements → changes → verification → merge into a semi‑automated assembly line.

2) What work will be “accelerated” or even “replaced”?

Section titled “2) What work will be “accelerated” or even “replaced”?”
  1. Boilerplate, CRUD, repetitive scaffolding — the most common AI use case. In Stack Overflow’s 2024 survey, among developers who use AI, 82% use it to “write code.”
  2. Small‑to‑medium feature work and debugging — GitHub and academic controlled studies show developers using Copilot complete tasks 55.8% faster.
  3. Tests, docs, migrations — trend reports and frontline practice alike reinforce that AI is taking over the grunt work, letting humans return to design and decision‑making.

3) Risks and pitfalls not to ignore

Section titled “3) Risks and pitfalls not to ignore”
  • Security regression risk: multiple studies indicate developers using code‑gen AI are more likely to produce insecure code; industry reports likewise note that more than half of developers frequently see security issues in AI suggestions.
  • Lack of understanding and over‑reliance: recent surveys show 59% of developers use AI‑generated code they don’t fully understand, creating quality and maintainability hazards.
  • Trust and quality gap: leaders and community voices stress that AI is powerful, but doesn’t automatically ship products faster — we need mature engineering methods and human gatekeeping.

4) How the engineer’s role is shifting

Section titled “4) How the engineer’s role is shifting”
  • From “implementer” to “designer and verifier”: leaders broadly agree developers will invest more in architecture, validation, and AI supervision.
  • From “writing functions” to “building factories”: connect Claude Code commands, Sub‑agents, CI security reviews, and Cursor Agent to build an end‑to‑end automated pipeline.

5) A 90‑day action plan (copy‑ready)

Section titled “5) A 90‑day action plan (copy‑ready)”

Days 0–30: Standardize the process

  • Provide a Spec template (user stories, boundaries, acceptance criteria).
  • In Claude Code, implement common Slash commands such as /create-mvp, /write-tests, /changelog.

Days 31–60: Shift security left

  • Add the Claude Code Security Review GitHub Action to the repo so every PR is scanned automatically with suggested fixes.
  • Set blocking rules and allowlists to reduce false positives and noise.

Days 61–90: Orchestrate the intelligence

  • Use Sub‑agents for a “test agent, docs agent, migration agent.”
  • In Cursor, combine Agent / Ask modes — Ask to read the codebase first, then modify.

6) Opportunity map for individuals and teams

Section titled “6) Opportunity map for individuals and teams”
  • New roles: Agent Ops (keep agents running reliably), Prompt QA (turn natural language into acceptance cases), security review collaboration (AI + SAST/DAST).
  • 10× individuals: one person can use Cursor/Claude Code to stand up the pipeline from scaffolding to deploy; small teams can punch above their weight.
  • Organizational compounding: codify useful Slash commands, Sub‑agents, and checklists in the repo — the more you use them, the smoother it gets.

7) Two suggestions for managers

Section titled “7) Two suggestions for managers”
  1. Bake “human‑in‑the‑loop” into the process: before merging code, require both AI security review + human review.
  2. Measure ROI with data: compare pre/post‑AI lead time, defect rate, rollback rate, refactor frequency — don’t just look at commit counts. The industry debate is a reminder to let metrics do the talking.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

AI isn’t here to steal keyboards; it’s here to reshape the production line. Lots of people can write code; far fewer can build an AI‑driven production line. State requirements clearly, contain risk, and choreograph intelligence — that’s the core competitive edge of the next‑gen engineer. Are you ready?

Food for thought: What are the first three things your team could “automate”?
How would you turn them into Slash commands or Sub‑agents?

item.title: Vibe Coding vs. Traditional: Stop Typing, Start Shipping
item.content:encoded:
Vibe Coding vs. Traditional Programming — key differences:

  • Vibe Coding: driven by natural language; you act as a director; focus on the end result; progress by questioning and dialogue. It’s fast and lowers the barrier, but can lead to a black‑box understanding.
  • Traditional programming: precise programming languages; you act more like an architect; focus on implementation details; emphasize algorithms and principles. It’s slower and higher‑bar, but yields deep code understanding.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Over the past two years, writing code has increasingly become an exercise in making intent explicit. Editing projects directly with natural language, refactoring across files, and auto‑generating PRs are now everyday workflows:

  • Tools like Cursor/VS Code support natural‑language edits to entire code blocks and cross‑file changes.
  • Replit Agent emphasizes “describe in everyday language and get a runnable app.”
  • Claude Code in the terminal turns “idea → code” into an end‑to‑end workflow. Adoption is surging: Stack Overflow’s 2024 survey shows 76% of developers use or plan to use AI helpers.

What Is Vibe Coding?

Section titled “What Is Vibe Coding?”

In one line: Define goals in human language → let AI draft first → humans calibrate scope and acceptance via dialogue. It’s not mystical “going by feel,” but rather turning intent, constraints, and acceptance into an executable collaboration language. Typical vehicles include natural‑language code edits in AI editors and dialog‑driven tasks/batch changes in the terminal/IDE.

Seven Differences from the Comparison Chart (Practical Read)

Section titled “Seven Differences from the Comparison Chart (Practical Read)”
  • Input: Vibe uses natural language + examples; traditional relies on design docs + handwritten implementation.
  • Role: Vibe is like a director, breaking down shots and pacing; traditional is like an architect, setting structure and detailing.
  • Focus: Vibe stresses runnable results; traditional stresses a traceable process.
  • Skills: Vibe emphasizes questioning and acceptance writing; traditional emphasizes algorithms and language details.
  • Cadence: Vibe iterates fast; traditional moves steadily.
  • Barrier: Vibe is lower, good for cross‑functional alignment; traditional is higher, good for high‑reliability domains.
  • Cognition: Vibe tends toward black‑box; traditional is auditable.
  • Key takeaway: Vibe is a communication‑paradigm upgrade, not a replacement.

Six Everyday Dev Scenarios: Vibe Flow vs Traditional Flow (Copy‑Ready)

Section titled “Six Everyday Dev Scenarios: Vibe Flow vs Traditional Flow (Copy‑Ready)”

1) Feature 0→1: Add “WeChat QR Login” to Next.js

Section titled “1) Feature 0→1: Add “WeChat QR Login” to Next.js”
  • Traditional: write requirements → choose library → draw sequence → branch → implement → PR.
  • Vibe (dialogue in Cursor/Claude Code):
    1. “Project is Next.js + Supabase, need a minimal WeChat QR login. Constraints: only touch the auth module, don’t change the existing user table.”
    2. Have AI generate routes, callbacks, and env var checklist, plus security and rollback notes.
    3. Ask for a PR description + E2E acceptance steps. Why it works: natural‑language cross‑file edits + auto PR/test checklists.

2) Fast Regression for a Production Bug

Section titled “2) Fast Regression for a Production Bug”

  • Traditional: dig logs → reproduce locally → patch → write regression tests.

  • Vibe:

    • Paste exception logs + relevant functions: “Provide the smallest diff fix, and generate the regression unit test and repro scenario.”
    • Humans focus on blast‑radius review and boundary checks. Essentials: small PR + must‑test + rollbackable.

3) Repo‑Wide Migration: axios → fetch

Section titled “3) Repo‑Wide Migration: axios → fetch”

  • Traditional: global search → manual replace → fix file by file.

  • Vibe:

    • “Scan axios usage, design a unified wrapper and a batched change plan (prioritize low‑risk directories), ship each batch with a rollback script.”
    • Let AI batch‑apply changes; humans ensure error‑handling strategy in the wrapper layer is solid. Tooling: natural‑language cross‑file rewrites.

4) Performance Tuning: Slow DB Queries

Section titled “4) Performance Tuning: Slow DB Queries”

  • Traditional: explain → index → adjust SQL/cache.

  • Vibe:

    • “Here are the slow‑query logs + schema. Propose a three‑step optimization order: validate index gains first, then consider caching; output target P95/QPS and a baseline script.”
    • AI produces SQL and metrics scripts; humans run benchmarks and do canary rollout.

5) Pre‑Review for Code Reviews

Section titled “5) Pre‑Review for Code Reviews”

  • Traditional: reviewer scans logic manually.

  • Vibe:

    • Have AI produce a pre‑review summary (high‑risk changes, uncovered paths, potential injection spots),
    • Humans gatekeep business semantics and compliance. Benefit: reviewers spend time on critical semantic judgment.

6) Personal Projects/Newcomer Onboarding

Section titled “6) Personal Projects/Newcomer Onboarding”

  • Traditional: read docs, poke around the repo.

  • Vibe:

    • Describe the tool/page you need; an agent scaffolds and runs it — great for spin‑up in an afternoon.

Risks and “Guardrails”

Section titled “Risks and “Guardrails””

  • Black‑box feel: many can use the tools yet don’t fully understand the generated code; industry surveys flag this as a risk.

  • Guardrail checklist (strongly bake into templates/commands):

    • PR template: background, acceptance criteria, impact surface, rollback.
    • CI: must‑run tests, coverage thresholds, dependency and license scanning, secrets scanning.
    • Conversation templates: goals/MVP/disallowed changes/log level/time‑budget and rate limits.
    • Slash Commands: codify common flows so the team can reuse with one command.

When to Use Vibe — and When Not Yet

Section titled “When to Use Vibe — and When Not Yet”
  • Great fit: prototyping, CRUD features, bulk renames/refactors, scaffolding, repetitive fixes.
  • Don’t fully “outsource” yet: high‑security/strict‑compliance systems, core algorithms, modules requiring strong performance explainability.
  • Team readiness: shared PR/test templates, clear rollback conventions, and at least one one‑command project bootstrap + acceptance script.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

The essence of Vibe Coding is a communication upgrade: turning human intent into machine‑executable steps. It doesn’t think for you — it makes the boundaries of your thinking clearer. As a next step, take your team’s three most common tasks and turn them into reusable conversation templates/Slash commands — you can speed up starting today.

item.title: Conductor Orchestrates Multiple Claude Code Agents
item.content:encoded:
Conductor: Orchestrate Multiple Claude Code Agents Together

Section titled “Conductor: Orchestrate Multiple Claude Code Agents Together”

In one sentence: Conductor lets you spin up multiple “Claude teammates” at once, each with its own isolated git worktree, so different tasks progress in parallel; you can also see who’s working, who’s stuck, and what changed — all at a glance.

—

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

For complex projects, parallel progress is the productivity unlock. The traditional approach means opening lots of terminals, manually splitting branches, hopping directories — and it’s easy to step on each other’s toes. Conductor turns that workflow into a visual control panel: with a few clicks, you can have multiple Claude Code instances working in their own isolated workspaces simultaneously. It also supports local/GitHub/any Git URL repositories, multi‑tab terminals, Slash commands, message queues, and archiving scripts — the practical stuff you actually need.

❗️Note: This article’s Conductor refers to the macOS app from conductor.build, not the Netflix/Orkes microservices workflow engine “Conductor OSS.” Don’t mix them up.

Highlights & Capabilities

Section titled “Highlights & Capabilities”

1) Visual multi‑agent parallelism: see who’s running, who’s blocked, and what changed

Section titled “1) Visual multi‑agent parallelism: see who’s running, who’s blocked, and what changed”

Each Claude Code instance works independently, while the UI shows status and diffs — a team‑like collaboration experience.

2) Real isolation: each workspace is a new git worktree

Section titled “2) Real isolation: each workspace is a new git worktree”

Not just a temp folder — it’s one worktree + branch per agent, preventing overwrites and conflicts. The official FAQ is explicit: “Yes, each workspace is a new git worktree.”

3) Works with local repos, GitHub, any Git URL

Section titled “3) Works with local repos, GitHub, any Git URL”

Recent changes added local repository support; you can also one‑click clone remote repos and work entirely on your Mac.

4) Built‑in terminal with multiple tabs

Section titled “4) Built‑in terminal with multiple tabs”

Changelog entries repeatedly mention fixes/improvements for terminal tabs, confirming multi‑tab terminal support is built in.

5) Slash commands built in: capture frequent actions into short commands

Section titled “5) Slash commands built in: capture frequent actions into short commands”

The official updates announce Slash commands are live, manageable in settings; they pair nicely with Claude Code’s own Slash mechanism.

6) Message queue and archiving scripts

Section titled “6) Message queue and archiving scripts”

The changelog mentions a message queue (process multiple messages in order) and optional archiving scripts, making it easy to turn conversations and outputs into a traceable asset.

7) Reuse your existing Claude login/keys

Section titled “7) Reuse your existing Claude login/keys”

Conductor directly uses your current Claude Code setup (API key, Pro or Max plan). No redundant configuration.

Installation & Preparation

Section titled “Installation & Preparation”

Platform: currently a macOS app; visit the website and click Download Conductor.

Prep Claude Code: install and ensure Claude Code CLI/native binary works locally (see the official installation script/docs).

First run:

  1. Open Conductor and add a repository as prompted (local path / GitHub / any Git URL).
  2. Choose the number of Claude Code agents to start and give each a task description.
  3. The app will create an independent worktree + branch for each agent and begin execution.

Getting Started: 3 Parallel Scenarios for Everyday Development

Section titled “Getting Started: 3 Parallel Scenarios for Everyday Development”

Scenario A: Fix tests while running Lint and formatting

Section titled “Scenario A: Fix tests while running Lint and formatting”
  • Agent A: fix failing unit tests and assertions
  • Agent B: run ruff/black/eslint/prettier, etc.
  • Agent C: update CI configuration in sync Each agent works on a separate worktree branch without interference; merge them one by one afterward.

Scenario B: Safe rollout + canary/rollback choreography

Section titled “Scenario B: Safe rollout + canary/rollback choreography”
  • Agent A: refactor authentication logic
  • Agent B: write rollback scripts and feature flags
  • Agent C: add SLO monitoring and alerts Turn these into Slash commands like /ship feature-x, /prepare rollback so one tap runs the whole flow.

Scenario C: Documentation and knowledge capture

Section titled “Scenario C: Documentation and knowledge capture”
  • A message queue lets you “throw tasks in to be processed in order,” then batch‑review the results
  • Use archiving scripts to package key conversations, change logs, and outputs (e.g., pre‑release dossiers) (Both features are noted in the official changelog; combine with your team’s conventions for automation.)

Workflow Suggestions (Aligned with Claude Code Best Practices)

Section titled “Workflow Suggestions (Aligned with Claude Code Best Practices)”
  • Crisp task splitting: each agent focuses on one goal (e.g., Auth refactor / new reports page / DSL parser)
  • Maintain isolation: use separate worktree branches for different tasks to avoid blocking and improve merge quality/speed.
  • Template commands: collapse common prompts into Slash commands, turning “boilerplate chatter” into “one‑line instructions.”

Quickstart Checklist

Section titled “Quickstart Checklist”
  1. Install Claude Code (if you haven’t).
  2. Download and open Conductor.
  3. In Conductor, add a repository (local / GitHub / Git URL).
  4. Create multiple agents and write their individual tasks.
  5. Watch logs/commands in the multi‑tab terminal; use the message queue when needed to send batched messages in order.
  6. Use Slash commands to reuse your favorite workflows.
  7. When done, use archiving scripts to package artifacts, or merge branches and ship.

Gotchas & Comparisons

Section titled “Gotchas & Comparisons”
  • Don’t confuse it with Conductor OSS: that’s a microservices orchestration platform (Netflix/Orkes community) — different from this Claude Code GUI.
  • Claude Code only (for now): the FAQ says, “Right now, just Claude Code. Others coming soon.” Don’t expect other models immediately.
  • Performance: parallelism consumes local resources; control agent count and use the message queue to pace execution.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Conductor = multi‑agent parallelism + worktree isolation + visual control. If you constantly juggle multiple tasks and worry about stepping on changes, this tool can instantly boost throughput and flow. Paired with Slash commands and archiving scripts, it turns “manual processes” into standardized buttons and converts “dialogue outputs” into a traceable knowledge base.

Do you think this “multi‑agent in parallel” approach fits your projects? How would you split tasks? Share your experience in the comments.

item.title: Claude Code and Cursor read browser console logs via Browser Echo

Stream the browser’s console.* logs and errors, in real time, **“echo”** back to your local terminal; zero-config out of the box, perfect for AI coding assistants that read terminal output such as Cursor / Claude Code / Copilot CLI / Gemini CLI.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Can’t reproduce in production, no stack trace locally, and your AI assistant can’t see frontend logs? Browser Echo streams browser logs directly to your development terminal, non-intrusive to your code and no impact on production bundles, complete with file:line numbers and stack traces. Once the AI assistant can read the errors, it can generate fixes right inside Cursor or Claude Code.

Highlights

Section titled “Highlights”
  • Optimized for AI coding assistants: terminal-friendly output; works directly with Cursor, Claude Code, Copilot CLI, and Gemini CLI.
  • Framework-agnostic, plug-and-play: React/Vue, the Vite family, TanStack Start, Nuxt 3/4, Next.js—all covered; custom integrations supported as well.
  • Development-only: no injection into production bundles; enabled by default only in dev mode.
  • Frontend logs that feel like backend logs: batched reporting, sendBeacon, file:line:col source info, stack traces, colorized terminal output.
  • Vite optional file sink (Next/Nuxt default to stdout).
  • Open-source MIT, actively updated: latest is v0.0.6 (2025-08-12).

Who should use it

Section titled “Who should use it”
  • You fix frontend bugs inside Cursor / Claude Code but can’t see the browser console.
  • You need client-side exceptions surfaced immediately to your terminal (or a file) for quick diagnosis.
  • Local reproduction is hard, and you want a smoother loop where AI reads logs → proposes a fix PR.

Tools like Datadog/Grafana RUM provide aggregated production metrics and alerts; Browser Echo focuses on local development debugging and AI collaboration, optimizing for fastest feedback and terminal readability. They complement each other.

Closing

Section titled “Closing”

With Browser Echo, frontend errors no longer “get stuck in the browser.” Spot issues at a glance in the terminal, and let AI fix them in one go. Install it, and you’ll feel your frontend “closed-loop speed” noticeably increase. Add it to your Next project and give it a spin today.

item.title: Claude Code’s Opus Plan Mode: Cheaper and Smarter
item.content:encoded:
Claude Code’s “Opus Plan Mode” = Plan with Opus, execute with Sonnet. It turns what we’ve been doing manually — “Opus thinks, Sonnet does” — into a one‑click strategy: let the stronger Opus handle complex reasoning, and let the more cost‑effective Sonnet actually write and modify files.

How to Enable

Section titled “How to Enable”
  • In the terminal, type /model and select the Opus Plan Mode option from the menu; use /status anytime to check the current model.
  • Enter/exit Plan Mode: press Shift+Tab (most terminals require two quick presses). In this mode it only analyzes and plans — it won’t edit files or run commands.
  • When you’re ready to actually implement, exit Plan Mode (via shortcut or the ExitPlanMode tool).

Why It Saves Tokens

Section titled “Why It Saves Tokens”
  • Official pricing: Opus 4.1 $15/$75 (input/output per million tokens), Sonnet 4 $3/$15. Opus is roughly 5× more expensive. Use it only for “thinking/planning” and hand code generation to Sonnet — your costs drop accordingly.
  • Additionally, Claude Code has a default hybrid strategy: start with Opus up to a quota, then automatically switch to Sonnet (recommended default). It balances “power vs. cost”.

When to Use It

Section titled “When to Use It”
  • Unfamiliar repo analysis → solution design → task breakdown: In Plan Mode, have Opus summarize the architecture, list change steps and acceptance criteria; once confirmed, execute. Plan Mode itself supports “analyze only, no hands-on changes”.
  • High‑risk changes (upgrades, refactors, migrations): first have Opus write a detailed implementation plan and rollback strategy, then use Sonnet to implement step by step.
  • Long‑running agents: decoupling planning from execution keeps costs controllable and moves closer to agents that can run complex tasks for extended periods.

Tips

Section titled “Tips”
  • Want safer defaults: set permissions.defaultMode to plan so you plan first, execute later.
  • Use /model to switch combinations on the fly (e.g., temporarily use Opus end‑to‑end to get past a roadblock).

Notes

Section titled “Notes”
  • Heavy users may encounter new weekly limits for now (mainly targeting 24/7 “whale‑style” agent usage). During planning, articulate the approach clearly and reuse plans to reduce wasted reasoning.

In short: Opus “thinks it through,” Sonnet “gets it done.” Same progress, lower cost, and the “plan → execute” cadence becomes a baked‑in workflow. Your intuition is spot‑on — this does push agents a step closer to “complex tasks that can run long and steady”.

In one sentence: terminalcp = Playwright for the terminal.
It lets an AI agent start, operate, and read any command‑line tool (LLDB/GDB, Python REPL, database shells, even other AI CLIs) like a human—and lets you and me take over the same session at any time.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

You may already use Playwright/Browser for web automation—so what about an “automation console” for the command line?
terminalcp abstracts “what a human does in the terminal” into an MCP tool: start a process → send keystrokes → read output → manage multiple sessions, and also supports socket attach so you can watch and take over the AI’s actions in real time.

Why add it to your toolchain?

Section titled “Why add it to your toolchain?”

1) Truly interactive control
Not just “run a command and exit,” but persistent sessions: single‑step in LLDB/GDB, try code in a REPL, or view the “full screen” in TUI apps like vim/htop.

2) Two output modes, pick as needed

  • Terminal mode (stdout): captures the rendered screen buffer, perfect for debuggers and TUIs.
  • Stream mode: captures the raw text stream (ANSI stripped by default), and supports incremental reads with since_last—more efficient for builds/logs.

3) High‑fidelity PTY
Processes run in a pseudo‑terminal, preserving colors/cursor moves/special key sequences—just like human input; plus it manages multiple processes in the background so your agent doesn’t block.

4) Socket attach: the key to human–AI collaboration
Each process automatically exposes a Unix domain socket. You can attach to an already‑running AI session to co‑view and co‑operate, jumping in to help anytime.

5) More “AI‑friendly” than screen/tmux

  • Structured responses (JSON) instead of a wall of text.
  • Clean output (ANSI can be stripped), easier to feed into an LLM.
  • Incremental reads and lifecycle management (exit codes, etc.) built in.

item.title: GPT-5 Front-End Web Development: Best-Of Stack
item.content:encoded:
If you plan to use GPT-5 in front-end work, I strongly recommend this combo—Next.js (TypeScript) + Tailwind CSS + shadcn/ui + Radix + Motion + (Material Symbols / Heroicons / Lucide) + Inter/Geist/Mona Sans/IBM Plex Sans/Manrope fonts. This stack is stable and fast, and it lets GPT-5 fully leverage its long context and fresher training corpus. GPT-5 offers a 400K-token total context (about 272K input + 128K output/thinking), so it can hold entire requirements pages, component library APIs, style conventions, and long code blocks—showing noticeably better “on-the-rails” output for TS/CSS/HTML.

Why GPT-5?

Section titled “Why GPT-5?”
  • It fits more: With 400K context, you can pack complex pages, interface contracts, and design specs while the model keeps state across turns, with fewer “dropped threads.”
  • More collaborative: With “reasoning built in,” planning for complex tasks is clearer; ideal for having it spin up the project skeleton in one pass, then refine components.
  • Better at code: In my experience, TS, CSS, and HTML outputs are crisp and consistent—naming is unified, utility classes are restrained, and PR review is lighter.

Recommended Engineering Stack (and how GPT-5 complements it)

Section titled “Recommended Engineering Stack (and how GPT-5 complements it)”

1) Framework & Language: Next.js + TypeScript

Section titled “1) Framework & Language: Next.js + TypeScript”
  • Why: First-class TS, zero-config start, clear directories, natural server/client component boundaries. For GPT-5, clearer constraints produce steadier generations.
  • Practice: Provide tsconfig.json, eslint rules, and an example app directory. Ask GPT-5 to bootstrap the scaffold to your conventions, and keep subsequent work within the same ruleset.

2) Styles/UI: Tailwind CSS + shadcn/ui + Radix

Section titled “2) Styles/UI: Tailwind CSS + shadcn/ui + Radix”
  • Tailwind: Stable utility semantics make it easy for GPT-5 to compose and reuse. When you need specific values, bracket syntax works well.
  • shadcn/ui: Not a black-box library—components are copied into your repo. That’s ideal for AI generation/refactor; GPT-5 can modify your code directly.
  • Radix Primitives: Accessibility-first, composable primitives. Paired with shadcn’s theming layer, you get low effort with deep customization.

Pro tip: Consolidate your design constraints (colors, radii, shadows) as a “Tailwind theme config + shadcn component list.” Have GPT-5 read before it writes so it outputs a consistent UI in your vocabulary.

3) Icons: Material Symbols / Heroicons / Lucide

Section titled “3) Icons: Material Symbols / Heroicons / Lucide”
  • Material Symbols: Font-packed and simple to integrate—fast global rollout.
  • Heroicons: From the Tailwind team; direct React/Vue components; pairs naturally with utilities.
  • Lucide: Wide coverage, on-demand import, tree-shaking friendly.

Pro tip: Give GPT-5 an icon “allowlist,” e.g., Plus, Trash, ChevronDown, so it reliably reuses the same set and avoids style drift.

4) Motion: Motion for React (formerly Framer Motion)

Section titled “4) Motion: Motion for React (formerly Framer Motion)”
  • Componentized API with solid performance; integrates naturally with Radix and base HTML elements. GPT-5’s animation code is readable and maintainable.

5) Fonts: Inter / Geist / Mona Sans / IBM Plex Sans / Manrope

Section titled “5) Fonts: Inter / Geist / Mona Sans / IBM Plex Sans / Manrope”
  • Inter: UI-friendly, highly legible—rock-solid default body text.
  • Geist: Vercel’s modern, clean aesthetic—pairs nicely with Next.js visuals.
  • Mona Sans: GitHub’s variable font with a confident headline feel.
  • IBM Plex Sans / Manrope: Strong multi-language coverage, free for commercial use.

A Workflow That Lets GPT-5 Shine

Section titled “A Workflow That Lets GPT-5 Shine”

A. Provide full context once

Section titled “A. Provide full context once”

Bundle requirements, design specs, component list, routes/data models into a single long-context input. GPT-5’s 400K window can take it, reducing back-and-forth.

B. “Skeleton first, then flesh it out”

Section titled “B. “Skeleton first, then flesh it out””

Prompt outline:

  • “Use Next.js App Router + TS to scaffold pages: /, /login, /dashboard; components based on shadcn/ui; forms use Radix Dialog; styling with Tailwind utilities only.”

It will first produce a directory tree, component list, and interface contracts. In a follow-up, ask it to add tests, motion, and icon replacements.

C. Lock in your Design Tokens

Section titled “C. Lock in your Design Tokens”

Share tailwind.config.ts (colors, radii, spacing) and reusable class conventions. GPT-5 will stick to your taste and won’t get progressively noisier.

D. Make it your “docs worker”

Section titled “D. Make it your “docs worker””

Ask GPT-5 to generate README/usage examples/accessibility notes for each component. Radix semantics are easy for it to summarize.

Mini Hands-On (ask GPT-5 to generate/modify)

Section titled “Mini Hands-On (ask GPT-5 to generate/modify)”

Paste the commands above, your tailwind.config.ts, brand colors, and border radii into GPT-5. Say: “Using my config, generate a login page + dashboard + top nav + sidebar. Deliver TSX + Tailwind utilities; no inline styles; icons strictly from Lucide: LogIn, Settings, User. ”

Common Pitfalls & Fixes

Section titled “Common Pitfalls & Fixes”
  • Style sprawl: Fix three spacing steps (e.g., 8/12/16) and two shadow levels so Tailwind utilities don’t explode.
  • Inconsistent component look: Use shadcn templates + Radix interactions as the “single source of truth.” Let GPT-5 modify component source directly.
  • Random icon choices: Provide an icon allowlist and emphasize “only use these” in the prompt.

Closing

Section titled “Closing”

In one line: Feed GPT-5 with rules, and it will feed your front-end with rule-based consistency. With long context and a clear engineering stack, this generation already delivers productivity and polish in the front end. You don’t need it to “write everything”—you need it to standardize the grunt work while you focus on taste and trade-offs.

Storybook lowers the bar for “telling a good story” to simply “saying a sentence.” Chinese narration works, styles are playful, and print‑ready PDFs are easy to take with you. item.title: GPT-5 for Planning & Reviews + Claude Code for Implementation
item.content:encoded:
Conclusion first: GPT-5 excels at planning, structured design, and review/summary; Claude Code (Sonnet / Opus) is more reliable for hands-on execution and refactoring. In practice, the combo “GPT-5 plans + Claude Code builds + GPT-5 reviews” yields higher efficiency and fewer failures. What’s your take?

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

After the keynote, my first reaction was: GPT-5 isn’t just faster and more accurate—it thinks better. OpenAI exposed minimal reasoning and verbosity as tunable parameters, expanded context windows to 400K tokens with up to 128K output, and embedded Gmail/Google Calendar connectors directly into ChatGPT—available for Team today, with Enterprise/Education on August 14.

Media sentiment is consistent: fewer hallucinations, stronger coding, more “expert-like.” But a caveat—marketing charts backfired. Don’t trust vendor curves blindly; prioritize independent evaluations and real projects.

1. Where does GPT-5 actually excel?

Section titled “1. Where does GPT-5 actually excel?”

  • Controllable “thinking intensity”: API adds reasoning_effort="minimal", enabling faster responses without sacrificing much quality; verbosity dials answer length and information density. For engineers, these are your speed/quality knobs.

  • Much longer “working memory”: 400K context (about 272k in + 128k out) improves long-document handling and long-chain tool use.

  • Transparent pricing: $1.25 per 1M input tokens; $10 per 1M output tokens; mini/nano are cheaper.

  • Toolchain collaboration: OpenAI claims substantial gains on complex tool use (τ²-bench telecom scenario: 96.7%), fitting end-to-end agent workflows.

  • New ChatGPT experience: Mail and calendar connectors, personalized tone/voice, learning mode—lowering friction for everyday and team use.

In short: GPT-5 is a more steerable generalist—able to think shallow or deep on demand, and better at tools.

2. Hands-on impressions (with Claude comparison)

Section titled “2. Hands-on impressions (with Claude comparison)”

These are subjective notes from real-repo work—feel free to critique.

  • Blank-page code often misfires: Asking GPT-5 to write large backend blocks can show small API/stack mismatches—things that look right but break at runtime; Claude Code Sonnet / Opus feels steadier at “doing the painstaking work.” Opus 4.1 reports 74.5% on SWE-bench Verified, and it shows.

  • “Extend/modify by example” works great: Provide the project tree + key files + a minimal working example; GPT-5 follows style and integrates with existing interfaces more reliably, especially for UI/interaction—often green on first pass. Wired and TechCrunch also highlight broad improvements in coding and writing/analysis.

  • Benchmarks are strong—don’t deify them: OpenAI cites SWE-bench Verified 74.9%, Aider polyglot 88%; third parties show scenarios where GPT-5 ≈ Opus 4.1 ≈ Grok 4—differences vary by task. Don’t ship on scores alone.

My takeaway: I prefer GPT-5 for “blueprints” and “reviews”; for actual wrench-turning, Claude Code is less hassle.

3. Recommended workflow: GPT-5 plans + Claude Code executes

Section titled “3. Recommended workflow: GPT-5 plans + Claude Code executes”

Step 1 | Product/architecture design
Give GPT-5 the business goals, constraints, and non-functionals, and ask for system sketches, interface contracts, failure cases, and monitoring points. Prompt tip:

“Use verbosity=low for the summary; then high to expand risks by module.”

Step 2 | Task breakdown and acceptance
Have GPT-5 produce milestones → tasks → acceptance criteria, and a code change checklist (files, functions, risks).

Step 3 | Hand off to Claude Code
Provide the repo + task card + acceptance criteria to Sonnet/Opus; require branch-based development, stepwise commits, and rollback on failure. Opus 4.1 is particularly stable for multi-file refactors and debugging.

Step 4 | Two-way review
Let GPT-5 handle PR review, test additions, and changelogs; let Claude handle fixes and polish.

Step 5 | Long-chain automation
For complex pipelines (search/retrieval/many tools), favor GPT-5—OpenAI provides fresh evidence on long chains and instruction-following. But add human checkpoints at critical stages—don’t go fully hands-off.

4. When to choose which?

Section titled “4. When to choose which?”

  • 0→1 prototyping, front-end flair, ready-to-ship UX: lean GPT-5 (multiple outlets show stronger front-end generation and “software on demand”).

  • Large-repo renovations, long-running execution, fine-grained patchwork: lean Claude Code (Sonnet / Opus); the latest versions keep improving on real engineering tasks.

  • Cross-app coordination and daily office work: ChatGPT (GPT-5) + connectors is smoother.

5. Two sober reminders: avoid glossy charts; don’t worship leaderboards

Section titled “5. Two sober reminders: avoid glossy charts; don’t worship leaderboards”

  • Keynote charts had issues—OpenAI acknowledged the “chart fiasco.” Rely on the official docs and product pages.

  • Independent evaluations are incoming: Platforms like Vellum offer grounded cross-model comparisons; winners differ by dataset. Translate the problem into your real workflow—that’s what matters.

Closing

Section titled “Closing”

GPT-5 is the “better thinker,” Claude Code is the “better doer.”
Right fit: let GPT-5 set strategy, draft blueprints, and supervise; let Claude Code execute, stitch, and refine.
In 2025, this combo is the most reliable engineering play.

How would you split the work? Share your combo in the comments.

item.title: $12B vs $5B: The Revenue Surge Strategies Behind OpenAI and Anthropic's Success

The past six months have redefined speed limits in the generative AI race:

  • OpenAI’s annualized recurring revenue (ARR) skyrocketed from $6 billion to $12 billion in just 6 months.
  • Anthropic achieved a 5x leap from $1 billion to $5 billion ARR within 7 months.

Why did these two AI powerhouses simultaneously take off? More importantly, what drives their growth momentum, and what shifts might we see ahead? This analysis breaks down four key revenue streams to reveal the underlying currents shaping this competitive landscape.

1. Consumer Subscriptions: OpenAI Maintains Its Lead

Revenue StreamOpenAI 2025E ARRAnthropic 2025E ARRKey Drivers
Consumer Subscriptions$5.5B$0.7BChatGPT Plus, Teams, Student subscriptions

OpenAI’s consumer advantage is reinforced by ChatGPT Plus and Teams: the $20-30 monthly subscription model effectively converts massive free traffic into steady cash flow. In contrast, Anthropic has yet to develop a direct-to-consumer product of comparable scale.

Section titled “2. Enterprise & Partner Subscriptions: Microsoft’s Strategic Boost”
Revenue StreamOpenAIAnthropic
Enterprise & Partner Subscriptions$3.6B$0.9B

OpenAI benefits from deep integration with Microsoft 365 Copilot and Azure OpenAI Service: enterprises purchasing GPT-4o through Azure contribute to OpenAI’s partnership revenue. While Anthropic has partnerships with Google and AWS, their scale remains behind.

Section titled “3. API Revenue: Anthropic’s Only Leading Battleground”
Revenue StreamOpenAIAnthropic
Total API Revenue$2.9B$3.1B

API represents Anthropic’s only segment lead: the Claude 3/4 series has earned strong developer community reputation, capturing market share through competitive token pricing and stable performance.

Coding Use Cases = Anthropic’s “Accelerator”

Section titled “Coding Use Cases = Anthropic’s “Accelerator””
  • Cursor and GitHub Copilot combined contribute $1.4 billion ARR, accounting for nearly half of Anthropic’s API revenue.
  • The specialized Claude Code model (formerly Claude 3 Haiku-Code) grew from $200 million to $400 million ARR in just weeks.

Nearly all popular IDE plugins and browser extensions default to Claude 4 Sonnet, establishing Anthropic as the de facto standard in code generation.

4. Product Portfolio Comparison: Who’s More “Recession-Resistant”?

Revenue DiversificationOpenAIAnthropic
Consumer SubscriptionsStrongWeak
Enterprise SubscriptionsStrongMedium
APIMediumStrong

OpenAI maintains a more balanced structure; Anthropic heavily relies on developer APIs + coding, with high concentration meaning both flexibility and risk:

  • Upside: Continued leadership in coding capabilities can drive explosive ARR growth.
  • Risk: If GPT-5 or other models match coding performance and penetrate through price competition, API customers (especially Cursor, Copilot) might switch, immediately impacting revenue.

5. Potential Inflection Points Ahead

Section titled “5. Potential Inflection Points Ahead”

  1. GPT-5’s Coding Performance
    OpenAI has publicly recruited a “Code LLM” team. If GPT-5 significantly surpasses Claude 4 in code generation and automated unit testing, Anthropic’s moat could face serious challenges.

  2. Cost Structure Differences
    Anthropic relies on AWS Trn1/Trn2 while also purchasing Nvidia H100s; their compute and capital expenditure burden is heavier. OpenAI enjoys cost advantages on Microsoft’s custom supercomputers, enabling aggressive pricing to compress competitors’ margins.

  3. Vertical SaaS Competition
    Solutions like Replit Ghostwriter and Sourcegraph Cody are emerging with proprietary or multi-model routing approaches, reducing dependence on single API providers.

6. Implications for Developers and Investors

  • Developers: Claude 4 Sonnet remains the most cost-effective for coding tasks short-term, but consider multi-model compatibility early to avoid vendor lock-in.

  • Investors: Monitor both companies’ performance on code LLM benchmarks (HumanEval+, SWE-Bench, etc.) and enterprise customer renewal pricing—these directly reflect growth curve sustainability.

Conclusion
Both OpenAI and Anthropic are setting new revenue growth records, but their underlying “growth curve” logic differs fundamentally: the former diversifies across multiple fronts with wide moats; the latter sprints on a single high-growth track. Over the next 6-12 months, if the code generation “decisive factor” gets rewritten, the 2025 ARR rankings could see another major reshuffle.

item.title: Claude Code Running in Your Local Browser
item.content:encoded:
Claude Code Web UI (abbreviated as CUI) brings Claude Code from the terminal into your browser with a modern interface, parallel multi-session support, push notifications, and voice dictation. Simply run npx cui-server to launch, then log in to continue your AI programming tasks from any device.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Still stuck having “black screen conversations” with Claude in the command line? CUI upgrades your AI programming experience to a cloud IDE, letting you write prompts, run agents, and receive notifications right in your browser, with mobile device continuity support.

Key Features

Section titled “Key Features”

✨ Modern Design

Section titled “✨ Modern Design”
  • Built with React + TypeScript, responsive interface for desktop and mobile.
  • Auto-completion consistent with CLI, zero learning curve.

🚀 Parallel Background Agents

Section titled “🚀 Parallel Background Agents”
  • Supports simultaneous multi-task streaming output, no more queuing for complex projects.

📂 Task Management

Section titled “📂 Task Management”
  • CUI scans ~/.claude/ history, centrally displays tasks with one-click Resume / Fork / Archive.

🔔 Push Notifications

Section titled “🔔 Push Notifications”
  • Integrated ntfy, instant alerts when tasks complete or await authorization.

🎙️ Gemini 2.5 Flash Dictation

Section titled “🎙️ Gemini 2.5 Flash Dictation”
  • Connected to Google Gemini API, fast and accurate long-sentence voice-to-text.

Three-Step Quick Installation

Section titled “Three-Step Quick Installation”

  1. Environment Setup

    • Node.js ≥ 20.19.0.

  2. One-Click Launch

    The terminal will output a #token string, copy it for use.

  3. Browser Access Open http://localhost:3001/#<token> to log in.

TIP: Need remote access? Set server.host to 0.0.0.0 in ~/.cui/config.json, or use --host / --port parameters, then pair with Caddy reverse proxy to upgrade to HTTPS.

Advanced Usage

Section titled “Advanced Usage”

Parallel Multi-Tasking

Section titled “Parallel Multi-Tasking”
  • Check running sessions in the Tasks tab; long tasks can run in the background after closing pages, no disconnection worries.

Chat Shortcuts

Section titled “Chat Shortcuts”
  • / for commands, @ for files, maintaining the same muscle memory as CLI.
  • ⌘/Ctrl + Enter to send, space for new lines, small tricks to boost typing efficiency by 10%.

Voice Dictation

Section titled “Voice Dictation”
  • Export GOOGLE_API_KEY in your system first, then restart the server to enable voice input.

Real-Time Push

Section titled “Real-Time Push”
  • Install ntfy client on any device, subscribe to the same topic, get vibration alerts immediately when tasks finish, no more screen watching.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

CUI creates a “browser-visualized shell” for Claude Code’s capabilities, with lightweight installation + remote access + push ecosystem, making AI programming as smooth as browsing the web. What pain points are you most excited to solve with it? Share in the comments!
